DOC.HEAD: Army Secretary Pays Christmas Visit To Soldiers Wounded In Panama
LaserPhoto SA1
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers wounded in Panama, wearing Purple Hearts on their pajamas, enjoyed Christmas visits with relatives and celebrated the news that Gen. Manuel Noriega turned himself in. ``I feel glad that the beast is in chains,'' Staff Sgt. Terence Merlo said Monday during a visit to Wilford Hall Medical Center by Army Secretary Michael P.W. Stone. Merlo, who is in the military police, said he wished the man who had run Panama had turned up somewhere other than in the Vatican Embassy, where he requested asylum Sunday. ``I'm not sure that it was the best place for him to turn himself in for us to get gratification and achieve our ends,'' said Merlo, who suffered at least four gunshot wounds to the abdomen and a nick on the temple. Stone visited wards stacked with Christmas presents and full of visiting relatives at Wilford Hall and Brook Army Medical Center, where more than 80 servicemen were being treated. ``We have been vigilant in our defense of our values and the threat to the national interest. But vigilance has its price,'' Stone said after the visit. ``We honor the soldiers for their patriotism, bravery and courage.'' As he made his way around hospital rooms, giving Army medallions as gifts, Stone heard firsthand about the fighting. Merlo, 40, with his wife, daughters and other relatives at his side, said he and MP Spec. Robert Cuschleg of Columbus, Ohio, were ambushed in the darkness during the first day of the U.S. attack. Cuschleg, in the next bed, had a finger amputated because of an injury. Pfc. Mike Heyne, 21, of Ashland, Ohio, also at Wilford Hall, said he hoped Noriega's surrender would allow American troops to come home soon. ``I'm glad he did it this early,'' said Heyne, who was wounded by mortar fire. A small jar containing some shrapnel doctors removed from his waist sat next to his bed, and Heyne said he planned to keep it as a souvenir. First Sgt. Jose Western, 31, recovering at Brooke, also expressed delight that Noriega's whereabouts were finally known. ``I'm glad Noriega surrendered. It doesn't matter where he is, as long as he surrendered,'' said Western, of Fort Ord, Calif. So far 250 soldiers, including 15 on Monday, have been brought to San Antonio after being wounded in Panama. Three died en route and one died after arrival. Dozens have been transferred back to home bases or discharged, leaving 52 at Wilford Hall and 34 at Brooke Army Medical Center. On Christmas morning, soldiers read newspapers reporting Noriega's surrender and displayed Purple Hearts from their pillows or pajamas. Relatives exchanged gifts with the soldiers and some attended two Christmas Day services as they stayed at the hospitals with their wounded loved ones.
